definition: to have more work than one can deal with/to have one's hands full
to cross/to go over/to pass (time)/to celebrate (a holiday)/to live/to get along/excessively/too-
to come/to arrive/to come round/ever since/next

sentences.english: It is right the rush hour in our restaurant, so we are terribly busy.
sentences.chinese: 我们餐馆现在正是用餐高峰，所以有点儿忙不过来。

sentences.english: Since the Special Investigation Unit is overloaded with work, why not assign some of the work to other prosecutorial units?
sentences.chinese: 特侦组忙不过来，不能交给其他检察单位侦办吗？

sentences.english: I'd like to go with you; however, my hands are full.
sentences.chinese: 我很想和你一块儿去，可是我忙不过来。

sentences.english: Don' t give her any extra jobs ; she' s snowed under already.
sentences.chinese: 别再把额外的工作派给她了，她已经忙不过来了。

sentences.english: It was a controller's way of saying he was in trouble and had more than he could handle .
sentences.chinese: 这是调度表示他碰上了麻烦，忙不过来的一种说法。

sentences.english: Tianlong busy, ask for help from South of Jiangsu.
sentences.chinese: 天朗忙不过来，向苏南请求帮助。

sentences.english: My dear fellow, I cannot do anything for you today. I am extremely busy.
sentences.chinese: 孩子，今天我实在忙不过来，没有办法接待你。

sentences.english: She's too busy empathizing with whatever they're experiencing in their lives.
sentences.chinese: 她对客人们生活中的体验进行移情都忙不过来。

definition: to be up to one's ears in work (idiom)/to be unable to attend to other things at the same time
to look after/to attend to/to have in care
to rush/in a hurry/to worry about being late
to help/to lend a hand/to do a favor/to do a good turn
to do sth in place of sb else
lit. to continuously revolve/to work non-stop/to work around the clock (idiom)
lit. badly burned about the head (from trying to put out a fire) (idiom)/fig. hard-pressed/under pressure (from a heavy workload, creditors etc)
